attachments.title: W. E. B. Du Bois’ Hand-Drawn Infographics of African-American Life (1900)
attachments.text: Visually dazzling set of hand-drawn charts created by Du Bois, condensing an enormous amount of data on African-American life into aesthetically daring and easily digestible visualisations.
attachments.fallback: The Public Domain Review: W. E. B. Du Bois’ Hand-Drawn Infographics of African-American Life (1900)

text: whoa, these are beautiful... crazy how much design seems to have come full circle
There so many interesting secondary stories behind each of these graphics. Like, why are the marriage rates so lop-sided in each age bracket?

I'm sure you all read this last year but read it last night and thought it was really interesting. <@U0HPGQ4KH>  <@U0265G76F> <@U0HP6TFNX>   "As creative director, Gaudio has provoked Adidas designers to imagine the full social universe that will surround a product before sketching the first line. That’s “born from culture.” It means inhabiting the mind of the consumer and asking questions about her life — from the mundane to the philosophical — that they might not have considered in the past: What do my friends dress like? What music do we listen to? What are our hopes dreams and desires?"

attachments.title: The Man Who Made Adidas Cool Again
attachments.text: Paul Gaudio, Adidas’s quiet creative director, transformed its product line and turned a perennial runner-up into the hottest name in sportswear. How the 67-year-old brand harnessed the rise of 24/...
attachments.fallback: BuzzFeed: The Man Who Made Adidas Cool Again

text: "Gaudio is average build in a fitted black T-shirt and jeans, with a square chin, snowy stubble, and a calm, unassuming manner that subverts the cartoon of the tempestuous creative visionary. Employees I talked to described him as “extremely even-keeled” and “a stabilizing presence.” Born and raised in blue-collar Pittsburgh, he speaks with a tempered Western Pennsylvanian accent (“They’re lookin’ fer something really comfortable”; “They run to get in shee-yape”) and uses the expression “holy cow” with aplomb. " cc/<@U026PHQ3J>
there is a lot of good brand fodder in there - particularly the "co-creator" brand stuff - amy was talking about that just yesterday
Geez the word "Mulato"...I remember reading that in textbooks in grade school. Don't think i've seen that since.

"The third principle — “Daringly simple” — balances two warnings against each other. The main word, “simple,” is a caution against needless complexity — the cardinal design sin of reinventing the wheel. The modifier, “daringly,” preempts rote minimalism. It means, basically, “don’t be boring.”"
If you haven't read it - especially Compass team, but really anyone - I highly recommend. <@U026103R3> et al

attachments.title: YOY simulate embroidery with 3D printed wall stitching
attachments.text: japanese design studio YOY and K's design lab propose 'wall stitch' -- a 3D-printed system of signage.
attachments.fallback: designboom | architecture & design magazine: YOY simulate embroidery with 3D printed wall stitching
